  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-12429].
  {panel}

** Steps To Reproduce:
1) create and save a private jira filter (e.g. assignee = paul chambers, resolution = unresolved)
2) give it a custom column order, remove one or more columns (e.g. assignee, resolution)
3) use {jiraissues} macro to insert it into confluence page

** Expected Result:

Appearance of filter output in confluence approximates appearance in jira, including custom sort order, column order

** Actual Result:

Confluence honors the sort order of the jira filter, but not the column order (and hiding of columns).

** Additional Information (Setup/Notes/etc):

{jiraissues} macro does provide a 'column' parameter to control visibility and order of columns. So there is a workaround.

But as stated, you would expect that specifying a certain filter in the plug-in would include its appearance, not just its query.
fields.summary: jiraissues macro should display column order like in the original filter

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-12415].
  {panel}

Hyperlinked page titles in 2.8 and above are confusing and are messing up colour schemes. 

The confusion issue is the one already covered in [CONF-5795] for the last item in the breadcrumb trail. Users don't expect links to take them back to where they started!

The colour scheme issue is that now page titles are links, they take the global/space link colour. The only way to get the page titles to fit with a custom colour scheme is to change all global/space link colours so they're the same as the Heading text - but this makes it difficult to spot links at a glance...

Suggestions:

* Unlink page titles  (or give users an option to unlink)
* Add an option to the global/space colour scheme to set Page Title colours independently of links.
fields.summary: Unlink page titles in 2.8 and above (or at least provide option for customising page title colour)

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa} *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-12411]. {panel} The html used for rendering icon links is currently pretty ugly. Semantically incorrect and presents one of many Confluence violations of 508 compliance. In addition to that the use of {{nobr}} class causes many issues (broken design) when content contains links that should wrap on a new line, but can't because of this class. See [CONF-12207|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONF-12207] and attached screen shot. The patch attached to this JIRA represents modifications to atlassian-renderer needed to get rid of the ugly html and replace it with much cleaner CSS implementation of the same feature, which in addition to generating prettier code also allows links to wrap correctly when they are too long. I'm attaching screenshots of various links before and after the patch to show that the result looks the same, but links wrap correctly. Here is the difference in the html code: h4. before: {code:html}

foo
new link with title
new link
foo@foo.com
attachment


looong ling that wraaaaaaaaaaaapsss on to a new line after it reeeeeaches the end of this line

{code} h4. after: {code:html}

foo
new link with title
new link
foo@foo.com
attachment


looong ling that wraaaaaaaaaaaapsss on to a new line after it reeeeeaches the end of this line

{code} It might be even possible to drop the use of {{icon-position-\*}} classes and define the image position directly in {{icon-name-\*}} classes. I wasn't sure which css file was the best place to stick the code in, so I picked {{master.css}}, which looked the best for this code.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-12383].
  {panel}

Make Confluence Section 508 accessibility standard compliant.

http://www.section508.gov/

Indicative of the requirements are in the Voluntary Product Accessibility Template (VPAT) for Web-based Internet information and applications:

(a) A text equivalent for every non-text element shall be provided (e.g., via "alt", "longdesc", or in element content).	 	 
(b) Equivalent alternatives for any multimedia presentation shall be synchronized with the presentation.	 	 
(c) Web pages shall be designed so that all information conveyed with color is also available without color, for example from context or markup.	 	 
(d) Documents shall be organized so they are readable without requiring an associated style sheet.	 	 
(e) Redundant text links shall be provided for each active region of a server-side image map.	 	 
(f) Client-side image maps shall be provided instead of server-side image maps except where the regions cannot be defined with an available geometric shape.	 	 
(g) Row and column headers shall be identified for data tables.	 	 
(h) Markup shall be used to associate data cells and header cells for data tables that have two or more logical levels of row or column headers.	 	 
\(i\) Frames shall be titled with text that facilitates frame identification and navigation	 	 
(j) Pages shall be designed to avoid causing the screen to flicker with a frequency greater than 2 Hz and lower than 55 Hz.	 	 
(k) A text-only page, with equivalent information or functionality, shall be provided to make a web site comply with the provisions of this part, when compliance cannot be accomplished in any other way. The content of the text-only page shall be updated whenever the primary page changes.	 	 
(l) When pages utilize scripting languages to display content, or to create interface elements, the information provided by the script shall be identified with functional text that can be read by Assistive Technology.	 	 
(m) When a web page requires that an applet, plug-in or other application be present on the client system to interpret page content, the page must provide a link to a plug-in or applet that complies with §1194.21(a) through (l).	 	 
\(n\) When electronic forms are designed to be completed on-line, the form shall allow people using Assistive Technology to access the information, field elements, and functionality required for completion and submission of the form, including all directions and cues.	 	 
(o) A method shall be provided that permits users to skip repetitive navigation links.

Jira has a request here: http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-5574
fields.summary: Section 508 Compliance for Confluence (VPAT)
Reduce line-height of title so wrapping doesn't look so ugly

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-12373].
  {panel}

As Confluence grow in size (eg. a few thousand of global spaces), inserting a link when editing a page will become slow (up to 10 seconds). 

This is because the pull down menu includes a listing of all the available global spaces.

Confluence site search (ie. dosearchsite.action) will also be affected as the spaces are listed the same way as when inserting a link.

A work around is to comment out the control block in *<confluence-install folder>/includes/common-space-select-box.vm* and comment out the code section that calls for Global spaces to be listed:
{code}
#*
    #if ($availableSpaces.size() > 0)
    <optgroup label="$action.getText('global.spaces')">
        #foreach ($option in $availableSpaces)
            <option value="$option.key" #if( $searchQuery.spaceKey == $option.key ) selected#end>$webwork.htmlEncode($option.value)</option>
        #end
    </optgroup>
    #end
*#
{code}

Similarly to disable Global Space listing in confluence search, modify *<confluence-install folder>/template/custom/space-select.vm*:
{code}
#*
    #if ($availableGlobalSpaces.size() > 0)
    <optgroup label="$action.getText('global.spaces')">
        #foreach ($option in $availableGlobalSpaces)
            <option value="$option.key" #if( $value == $option.key ) selected#end>$webwork.htmlEncode($option.value)</option>
        #end
    </optgroup>
    #end
*#
{code}
fields.summary: Slow link creation when there are numerous global spaces are involved - might also affect Confluence search

*Situtation*
- links using shortcuts must specify the tool-tip manually for each instance, there is no default

*Details*
- for a shortcut such as \[myword@wiktionary\], the default tool tip should read "Look up myword at wiktionary.org".
- I cannot specify a tooltip in the exapanded value, or the default alias
- I would like to specify the tool tip as something like "Look up %s at wiktionary.org"

*Recommendation*
- Add another column in global shortcut definitions that permit specification of a default tool-tip. 
-- Include %s injection of the ''shortcut word' in the tool-tip.
-- Include %k injection of the 'shortcut key' in the tool-top
- Include a _default_ default tool-tip of "Look up %s at %k" for any shortcut that does not have a specific tooltip pattern defined.
- the _default_ default tooltip can be overridded by the admin by specifying the 'Default Tooltip:" for each shortcut in the shortcuts admin panel.
- The tooltip for a specific link in a page can be overridden by a user specifying something like \[myword|myword@wiktionary|My tooltip\] if desired

Currently, the instructions we have available on [Migrate to Another Database|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Migrate+to+Another+Database] are lacking coverage for the scenario where XML backups are too large. Particularly large instances cannot use the XML export/import method due to the sheer size of the backup and limitations with the JVM Heap size on 32-bit Operating Systems. 

The exact problem is people in this situation are required to manually export the data from their existing database and then import it into their new database using their own DB tools (which is an appropriate step) however when it comes to setting up the connection to Confluence this becomes problematic, as the setup wizard detects that there is existing data and you cannot proceed without overwriting it.

This can be bypassed, by manually configuring the *confluence.cfg.xml* with the appropriate dialect settings, DB connection URL and login credentials but not all users will know how to do this (and we don't have documentation on it). 

One particular issue occurred recently when a customer attempted to migrate their existing MySQL Database to Oracle; the problem being this exact scenario - the setup instructions require you to run the setup wizard, which will consequently overwrite all the existing database to configure the new connection. The issue was resolved in the support case with instructions on how to configure the *confluence.cfg.xml* file, and he has since contributed a PDF containing detailed instructions on how to perform this type of migration (Thanks to Sherif Mansour). It would be handy if we could review this and add this to the appropriate section of our documentation linked to [Migrate to Another Database|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Migrate+to+Another+Database].
fields.summary: Update Migrate to Another Database instructions on CAC

There are a variety of rendering issues when using multiple dynamic tasklists in a table. The issues vary depending on whether its dynamic tasklist or dynamic tasklist 2.

To replicate, make a table like this:
{noformat}
|| *A* || *B* || *C* || *D* || *E* || *F* ||
| A | B | C | D | E | {dynamictasklist:Hari1} |
| A | B | C | D | E | {dynamictasklist:Hari2} |
| A | B | C | D | E | {dynamictasklist:Hari3} |
{noformat}

Add tasks of different names, then refresh the page.

1: Titles of tasklists are only the first name.
2: Tasks are munged so they all appear on all tasklists
3: For dynamic tasklist 2, it's rendered as if it's a nested table, which doesn't work.

This may be an unsupported configuration - in which case we should document that dynamic tasklists inside tables is not supported.

XML backups fail at a certain size, regularly. We recommend the alternative backup strategy:
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Alternative+Backup+Strategy+for+Large+Confluence+Sites

This is a more effective way to do backups anyways.  The xml backup should be a migrate-db-only solution. Other than that, DBAs should be expected to made db dump backups.

This should change in both the documentation and in the product. I am going to change the db setup guides to include this as a standard procedure when setting up an external db. Here's what would be nice for product-level changes:

1) An email notiification should be sent when an xml backup fails.
2) A banner should be displayed in <baseurl>/admin after a failed backup.
3) A note should be added to the hsqldb note about db backups after migration

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-11980].
  {panel}

The drop down menus (Add, Tools, etc) that have been added in 2.8.1 _do not work properly with [screen readers|http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Screen_reader]_. 

It is possible to use dynamic elements on a page so that a [screen reader|http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Screen_reader] can see them, and so that a blind user can navigate them, but the way that they have been implemented with this theme is not accessible. 

Specifically, the elements are not read out.

Changing the formatting to the Classic Theme is distinctly different from the formatting in the default that were used in 2.7. 

The CSS definitions for headings is off; the font size is dramatically smaller; the "recently updated" widget doesn't display in as nearly a friendly way.

Ideally this should include accessible coded java script with widget menu.

This means simply following good web development practices, such as:
* ensure content is placed in the DOM in document-semantic order
* use semantically relevant elements (e.g. <a> elements for navigation rather than spans)
* use alt tags, etc
fields.summary: 2.8 menus should be accessible by Screen Reader applications

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-11979].
  {panel}

When importing a large number of pages from disk using the "Import Pages from Disk" feature, the import begins, but the page eventually times out with an HTTP 503 error.  I can then manually return to the Dashboard, and view the pages in the space in question, and see that the import thread is still running.  It successfully completes, however there is no feedback provided to the user about whether the import was successful or not.

Steps to reproduce:

1) Create a directory with a large number (1765 was our count) of text files, ranging in size from 0.5K to 2K.  

2) Create a new space in Confluence.

3) In the Space Admin page, select "Import Pages from Disk".

4) Specify the directory containing the files.

5) Check the "Trim file extensions" checkbox.

6) Click Import.

7) Wait for the page to time out with HTTP 503.

8) Return the Confluence Dashboard

9) View the space into which you are importing the pages.

10) Verify that some pages have been imported, and that the import is continuing.  In Confluence 2.7, there used to be a total page count at the top of the alphabetic page listing, but that seems to have vanished in 2.8

What should have happened:

Confluence should provide some feedback to the user indicating either that the import will continue in the background, or perhaps block until the import is complete.  Ideally, Confluence would use DHTML or server-side push to continuously update the Import page with the progress of the import.
fields.summary: Import Pages From Disk doesn't provide progress updates for large numbers of files
